title: Cat Radio
description:
This project was created for Day 10 of Getting Unstuck. The purpose of today's challenge was to create a project that makes use of time-related blocks. 

If I had more time, I'd work on the script and playlist a bit more. But the time-related part was very fun to build and worked out better than I imagined. 

Spoken words: 
http://shtooka.net
https://en.wiktionary.org
https://www.tolearnenglish.com/free/words/findwords.php

Illustrations:
https://pixabay.com/en/radio-old-fashioned-retro-vintage-1293101/

Music: Lizzie Miles, Me and My Pillow
instructions: Cleaning out the closet one day, you come across an old radio. Does it still work? Find out by clicking the radio to turn it on.

title: The Time Laboratory
description:
Ugh! I definitely took on more than I anticipated with this project. I thought it would be really cool to know how long I've been alive. But calculating the number of days is SO complicated! So I did a very crude estimate. I marked this as draft because it's kind of a mess. It's hard to share work that I feel so uncertain about—but I think it's good for me. :) #learning

Images from https://commons.wikimedia.org/
Laboratory: https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Laboratory#/media/File:Photographing_Sound_in_1884._A_rare_photograph_taken_at_Volta_Laboratory_by_J._Harris_Rogers,_a_friend_of_Bell_and_Tainter_(Smithsonian_photo_44312-E)_i009.jpg

Scientist:
https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/f/f7/MARK_TWAIN%281883%29_p213_-_A_SCIENTIST.jpg
instructions:
The Time Laboratory is run by a nefarious cat named Sparkles, who wants all of your personal data! Sparkles has her assistant, Jeff, working late in the lab to collect data from you.

Press the green flag to meet Jeff and learn how long you've been alive.

title: Getting Unstuck Day 10: Digital Clock
description:
Thanks to @jsh for lots of support on the original project, and for moral support from @asparklekat and @karenb!

I tried to keep this pretty simple! I started by trying to make a digital clock. Then, I decided I wanted to make an analog clock—that's where things got tricky! I used the dots from my last project to make a little circle, and then incorporated the arrow keys. I figured out the angle for each by dividing 360 (degrees in the circle) by the number of seconds/minutes/hours. I had some difficulty with the initial direction the lines were facing, but eventually got it figured out!
instructions:
Press the green flag to see the current time.
Press a for analog mode.
Press d to go back to digital mode.

title: Digital Clock
description: This was actually my first time using the "current time" blocks - thank you to @karenb and @jsh for early time-related design challenges.
instructions: Press the green flag to find out what time it is! Complete with some fun (but maybe irritating longterm) sound.

title: Drops remix
description:
I LOVED @jsh's project so much that I both wanted to understand how it was working and also see how the sounds might shift over time. Remixing was a wonderful way to explore both of those! 

Shoutout to @paulinah and @karenb for helping me Get Unstuck! I had most difficulty getting the new bars and the ball objects to interact (change visually, create sound). My first strategy was to look for these features in the code, which brought me to a list which organized the sound structure. I'd never used lists before, so it was fun to explore to see what I could discover. What I discovered was that it wasn't the list I needed to be tinkering with at all. The buggy color sensing with ghost effects proved to be the culprit. Once that bug was isolated, and I was having difficulty remedying, I
SEARCHED ONLINE, 
TALKED IT OUT, 
and ASKED FRIENDS.
With their help, I was able to create the features I'd imagined for this remix! 

I added a few more bars, of decreasing size, that appear over time. I'm still fooling around with details, but am excited with where this is going (:
instructions: Press the green flag and enjoy!

title: Time Lab redux
description:
When @karenb shared her project on our ScratchEd group chat, I loved the idea and the sounds. It's a fairly straightforward project, and I've done things like this before, but when I looked inside, I was surprised to see that her code looked completely different from what I had been expecting. It's a reminder that there are many different ways to get things done. so I decided that my project for today would be a remix of Karen's, but I would add a few things to make it more organized. Once I reorganized the code, though, I was playing with the project and wondering if I was "done," a concept which I have been thinking about a lot. Was it enough? Did I put enough of "me" into this project?

But then an idea struck, and I was excited about how suddenly goofy the project was <-- that's definitely part of my style. ^_^
instructions: Press the green flag and follow along with the prompts. If you wait long enough, other Time Lab friends might appear...

title: My better alarm clock
description:
This is one of my favorite projects b/c I actually use the alarm clock feature from time to time in real life! (I created it last summer.)
I changed the orientation of the hand sprites so they can be coded while pointing in direction 0. I made adjustments for setting the alarm  by changing military time to standard time. I added code for the hour hand to change its position every minute. I cut the sound file so that it would end closer to exactly 60 seconds.
instructions:
Click the green arrow to turn on the clock.
Use the sliders to set the alarm clock.

title: Unstuck Day 10 Scratchy Bounce w/Timer
description:
The time-related blocks have always been one of my biggest stuck places, so thank you for this opportunity to Get Unstuck. I created this game for day 5 (jumping), but with a timer bar that I designed specifically to avoid using the timer. Today I went back to the project and replaced the bar with a variable that counts down from 100 by subtracting the timer. There is another script that waits until the timer is greater than 100 to end the game. Piece of cake!

 This is based on the Hasee Bounce game from the neopets web site: http://www.neopets.com/games/game.phtml?game_id=368
instructions:
Press the space bar to bounce one cat down and the other cat up. Time the jumping to catch the apples!
You can move each cat to the right and left with the right and left arrow keys.
Time is up when the timer reaches zero.
The apples speed up throughout the game!

title: Getting Unstuck: Day 10
instructions: Simple math quiz, you have only 5 seconds to answer the question....

title: Getting Unstuck #10
description:
I think I've invented the world's most annoying and inaccurate clock.

I was trying to think of alternative ways to represent time. This is hardly an exhaustive pair of approaches. If I had more time I'd think of a way to represent seconds. I'd also like the whole thing to be more musical. I'd try to get the breaths blowing up the balloon, and the frog's bounces to be in time with the ticking of the pendulum. 

PS- It's just turned midnight here, and at 00:00 it's a pretty uninteresting clock.
instructions: Just click the green flag.

title: Catch 5 Flies
description:
When a player 'wins' your game, do they want to play again?

'Replay value' is a big deal in game design. Even simple games take significant time and effort to code, and the we hopes the hours we put in will create, at least, minutes of fun for the players. This is a challenge, especially when we're new to making games.

I thought of this for Day 10 because the 'timer' block might be the lowest-hanging fruit for adding 'replay value' to a game. Playing a game with a timer changes the challenge from "can you do XYZ?" to "how well can you do XYZ?" Can you improve on your last performance? Will your time be faster than hers? The clock creates a relationship between each time you've clicked the Green Flag, and an incentive to do it again!

(I adapted this project from a game I wrote with @L2TT2L2018 last year)
instructions:
Jump with the UP ARROW
Catch flies with SPACE

How fast can you catch 5 flies?

title: Getting Unstuck: Day 10 — Binary Counter
description:
Reflection

I wanted to recreate an old Arduino project I once assembled that acted as a binary counter. It included 8 LEDs that represented the state of an byte, or 8-bit value, in memory.

The challenge for this project is that there are no bitwise operators (that I'm aware of) in Scratch. In order to simulate changing of the bits, I used a list so that each element of the list represents a bit. Building this 8-bit memory, along with the supporting functions, took most of the time.

Update: I went ahead a fixed the things I would have done if I had more time. Mostly refactoring and reorganizing. This involved rearranging and deleting unnecessary blocks, and separating and organizing the logic within the 4 sprites.
instructions: Move the slider to change the delay time of the binary counter.

title: Day 10 time
description:
The thing that took the longest time was to use the help sections for the blocks and see where to use forever and where forever was not needed.

With more time, I would like to round the days to an even number. 
Also, this would probably be a great exercise in Mapping. I wonder how to get 7 to say July and 8 to say August.
instructions: When I think of time, I thought of how long I'd been doing something.

title: Unstuck Day 10: Using Time blocks
description:
I made this project in response to the prompt for Challenge #10-time blocks- of the Getting Unstuck initiative from the ScratchEd Team:
https://gettingunstuck.gse.harvard.edu
This looks simple but was hard to figure out! I wanted to use timer to control a day/night cycle with the sine function. At first I thought there wasn't a sin block but then I found it. Then I had to figure out how to keep the tint of the sky, made by drawing with a big pen, in a positive value, as well as the brightness of the desert sprite. So I realized the absolute value block came in handy there. 
Math is hard so this was a good challenge!
instructions:
Day/night cycle using sin & cos of timer.
The lighting is good but as you can see I'm having a tough time with the rotation of the sun and moon. It's getting there...currently I have to figure out why they go clockwise sometimes in their cycle.
Eventually I figured out why but I can't fix it...

title: Getting Unstuck 10 - Travel
description:
Spent way more time on this than I planned. Headed to Red Sox game so out of time. I have a few things to add, days of trip, cat saying final time, etc. 

Had fun using those blocks and working out ways to convert the time. One note, had the arrival time clock go hour by hour to show the travel but taking a duck to California took a long time to spin. So I went without screen refresh. If you want to see the clock animate, edit that block on the arrival clock and watch that hour hand spin
instructions: click the flag and answer the cat's questions. He'll give you your arrival time at your location of choice by your transportation choice.

I created a list for each month containing the ordinal number for eachs day's place in the year. I left an example snippet of the list set up code on the stage.

With more time I would need to work out a fix for leap years.

title: 10 Second Maths Challenge (Unstuck#10)
description:
Getting Unstuck challenge/activity #10 - "Create a project that uses one or more of the time-related blocks in the Sensing category (i.e., timer, reset timer, current [year/month/date/etc.], days since 2000)"

Timer is used to set a 10 second limit on answering questions. Would be interesting to know if a "ask and wait" could be interrupted based on a timer or other event (at present as long as the question is within 10 seconds the user can take any length of time to answer due to the wait).
instructions: Click the flag to begin. Then click the button to start the challenge. How many questions can you get correct in 10 seconds?

title: Charlene's Timed Closet
description:
A remix of my Charlene's Closet https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/99536620/ based on a Math Forum Problem of the Week scenario.

Reflection: I thought it would be great to have your outfit chosen for you based on the day of the week and the weather.  I've tried to simulate that here a bit with one day lasting 60 seconds. Some choices are random, other more considered, like wear a hat when the sun is out or black socks at night (?). 

Getting Unstuck: I used a variable to help me set up the formula to choose which shirt to wear.  More time could be spent making the project more accurate, but I'm happy with the way it turned out.

It was nice to remix an project where all the costumes were set already.
instructions:
Getting Unstuck #10: Use the timer/ time sensing block.  

Time will tell Charlene what to wear when you click the Choose for me button.

Use the other buttons to make your own choice for Charlene.
Hats must be worn when the sun is out!

title: Getting Unstuck Day 10
description:
The Digi-Clock 2000 is an LED clock from the 1970's. It is hard to read and is decidedly clunky but now looks insanely cool.

I started just trying to make some sort of unusual linear/barchart clock, but it evolved over about 30 minutes' coding into this retro-silliness. Spent most of the time trying to get the right bar lit with silly 0/1 59/60 errors.
instructions:
Getting Unstuck Day 10

Create a project that uses one or more of the time-related blocks in the Sensing category (i.e., timer, reset timer, current [year/month/date/etc.], days since 2000).

for day 10 of Getting Unstuck

I got really stuck in this project, and eventually abandoned the idea of making a new kind of clock. Even building a counter or stop watch was confusing until I succumbed to using the "glide" block. In the end I'm aesthetically pleased and mathematically disappointed by my efforts.

title: Is it Friday? -- Unstuck Challenge 10
description:
This is just a silly little application that delights in its utter impractability. 

My original idea was to have the cat come out and report how many days left until the start of school, then after school started, the days left until the end of the year.  I decided that project was more than I could take on -- yet.  

Instead, I scaled down the idea to experiment with some of the blocks and concepts that might be necessary to make my original idea happen.  I think I have a better idea of how to go about it after playing with this project, but I may need to see what others have done first before I attempt my own project.
instructions: Just follow the on-screen instructions

title: Unstuck Day 10: Circles are on the Radar!
description:
Seem to be exploring geometry concepts in my projects . . . 
Working with circles is much more challenging than I expected!  Yesterday taught me to keep track of lines of code that I have tried, so today I created a new spite for each trial. 
Started by looking at "Digital Clock" by @mizzpeters and "My better alarm clock" by @Curious_AEF.  Curious to see how they created their circles.
When I got the project to work, I wasn't actually using the time-related blocks to accomplish the main task. Wanted solid radar colour to change when line pointing up, but haven't quite got that yet. Unfortunately, "time" is up for today!  May revisit.
Any suggestions and tips from experienced coders would be greatly appreciated!
instructions: Create a project that uses one or more of the time-related blocks in the Sensing category.  My idea was to create a radar-style circle effect and have the colour change once the circle is complete.

title: GU_Day10_PoisonIvy
description:
Lots of trial and error to figure out how to serrate the leaves! 
In this project I combined:  drawing with pen, color sensing, timing, and importing a photo (taken in my yard).
The user decides for how long to run around touching and/or avoiding poison ivy. Arrow keys are controlled by the user. I decided not to hide the person sprite at the end b/c I like how she is pointing up at the morals. In order to not have her speech bubble hide the morals, I needed to ditch the stop other scripts in this sprite block.
instructions:
Click the green flag.
When prompted, enter for how long to play. Use the arrow keys to move.

title: Clock (Getting Unstuck Day 10)
description:
I've used the timer blocks quite often, but I hardly ever use the current time blocks.

At first I wanted to make a water clock like the one I had seen in a Science Museum, but that turned out to be too complicated. Then I decided to go for this easier alternative and somehow it was a kind of magical moment that while I was still making this project another pink ball turned into a dark one because it was 8 o'clock overhere.

This only took me half an hour to make, but I enjoyed taking the challenge again. This is my third Unstuck project. One of my unstuck projects can be found on my main account @PinkyPepper.
instructions:
Just click the green flag and try to find out what time it is.

This project is made for day 10 of the Getting Unstuck Challenge:
Create a project that uses one or more of the time-related blocks in the Sensing category.

gettingunstuck.gse.harvard.edu

title: Getting Unstuck Day 10.1
description:
The Digi-Clock 2000 was an imaginary LED clock from the 1970's (https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/236398675/). It was hard to read. In response to complaints, the Digi-Clock Corporation made the Digi-Clock 2001 released in 1980 just in time for a new decade.

Just couldn't stop fiddling. This time I think you could actually use this clock.
instructions:
Getting Unstuck Day 10.1 - new and improved!

Create a project that uses one or more of the time-related blocks in the Sensing category (i.e., timer, reset timer, current [year/month/date/etc.], days since 2000).

*It is sometimes off by a day and for February may be off by 2

I thought it was a good way of playing and avoiding only serious information. We can learn and play, and we can be a bit as the deer as teachers too. :)

title: GettingUnstuck 10
description:
I like the concept for my project, having had many staring contests with my own cats.

I am a little stuck at the moment with the sensitivity on the video motion. If I set it to 99 or less, I can't get past a single second of the contest no matter how still I am, unless I actually hold my thumb over the webcam. But if I set it to 100, it doesn't pick up any motion at all. I tried varying whether it was measuring the motion on the stage or the sprite, and the result was the same. Maybe I'm just jittery?

Cat image by Thomas Wolfson via Pixabay.
Music is Home by Komiko via the Free Music Archive.
instructions: Click the green flag to have a staring contest with this cat.

I looked for inspiration within the studio because I was having a hard time deciding what to do. I got inspiration from @maths77680 project on multiplication. I have always wanted to do some type of Math quizzes. 

This was fun to do, but took me a while to debug and figure out how to do some of the things I wanted to do such as keeping track or correct vs incorrect answers.

title: Getting Unstuck Day 10: Let's Chat
description:
My project is a chat bot that uses the current month and day to calculate how many months until someone's birthday when they answer questions during the "chat". It also uses a timer to have the chat end after 1 minute. I ran out of time to work on this so the first 3 questions are more interactive than the remaining questions.

Sprite images created with https://www.bitmoji.com/

title: Getting Unstuck Day 10 Timer, Penguin and Rotating Fruit
Where are my kittens?
description:
My mini game was inspired on some elements of the "DK" arcade game.

                                     ---Questions---
+What took you the most time? 
I took me more time how to move the yarn ball along the stage and stop it at a certain time. I have also problems with the random position of each clone kitten.

+What would you do next with your project, if you had more time?
I'd like to move the yarn ball differently together with more levels.

                                       ---Credits---
+ Art design: characters and backgrounds are made with scratch paint editor.
instructions:
Press the start button.
Use RIGHT and LEFT arrow keys to move your cat.
Use SPACE key to jump.
Use UP arrow key to climb.
Try to get your kittens as quickly as possible.
When you get all kittens, don't forget to touch the other cat once and he will say you your time.
Enjoy it!!

---Getting Unstuck Day 10---

title: Unstuck 10 Timers
description: I wanted to create a project I could see student making in conjunction with Makey Makey. I used a timer to count down the number of seconds allowed for the answer button to be pressed. I also wanted to use a "list" variable to hold all the questions and answers. I still have the timing a bit off for the "say" commands, and I would have liked more time to include some animations to make it more interesting. Happy that I learned a bit about list variables and how to set them and check them.
instructions: Create a project that uses one or more of the time-related blocks in the Sensing category (i.e., timer, reset timer, current [year/month/date/etc.], days since 2000).

title: Getting Unstuck Day10
description:
What took you the most time? Originally I was going to edit Nano's costumes to go from baby to child, teen etc but it was taking ages. I've not used timing blocks before so I was too excited to get coding so I changed my plan.

What would you do next with your project, if you had more time? I think the idea is good but the execution is a bit poor. If I had more time I'd make this as a historical project 'Britain through the ages' or something with costume and background changes and a greater spread out timeline.

title: Getting Unstuck - Day 10 (time)
description:
Oh man. This was the hardest project yet. I've been trying to imagine my own ideas first before checking out other people's work for Getting Unstuck...but I've never used time-related blocks before! (gasp) So I broke my own rule and poked around a bit — and I saw a lot of numbers, which typically scare me off. But I wanted to push myself, so I looked for a basic structure to remix.

I knew one of my all-time favorite projects from 
@crazynimbus (https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/19013498/#editor) used a countdown, so I examined the scripts inside. Then I asked myself -- what date am I excited about? And realized I'm just happy that it's Saturday. And voila! I made a simplified time project that doesn't really use a countdown, but is a good start to thinking about computing with time.

Since I ask myself "Is it the weekend?" pretty much every day, I used my own sprite :)
instructions: How many days until the weekend? Click the green flag to find out!

title: Day 10
instructions: Click the green flag to start. Do not click until the green ball appears. The "time" will record your reaction time. Click anywhere on the screen to stop the time. See if you can get the best time.

title: Pizza success
description: I  realized when I had submitted the project that it was supposed to be time related. Oh well- it took a long time! I found out that you can download and edit images in the costumes part of the sprites using a combination of eraser and remove background. It works best if the background is fairly uniform. Next time I will take my own images though if possible as it will be quicker!  I suspect I can simplify the script for setting the variable counters if I look more closely at the operators and use some ratios.
instructions: I am always forgetting how many cups of flour I have added when making pizza so I made this counter to keep track! click on green flag and select the number of pizzas you wish to make. click on the flour and water cups to add the correct ratio of flour to water.

title: Unstuck Day 10 - Bug on a Donut
description: I had a tough time figuring out the sensing timer. I realized that it constantly runs, and that I'd be best off keeping it hidden. It does restart every time the flag is clicked. By having the donut say the time, the player knows how long it took the bug to land on the donut. The timer resets after each time the bug lands on the donut. I'd like to include a list of the last 5 times, but I'm not sure how to do that.
instructions: Press the flag. A timer is running. See how long it takes the bug to land on the donut. The timer will reset each time he leaves the donut.

title: 7 segment clock
description: I had a lot of fun with this one. I started out with an analog clock, but decided it might be more fun to try and replicate a classic LED 7 segement display based clock. The toughest part of getting this right is trying to create a 2d array for the truth table that dictates which combination of LEDs to use for each number. While I couldn't create a true 2d array, I got around the limitation by storing an array of strings and then using each character of the strings to represent an LED in the display.

title: The Tube Challenge_ Unstuck Day 10
description:
Many iterations. I was inspired while watching my boys swim in the hot summer sun. I began by making a swimming pool and inner tubes, then remixing a sprite to make Maya in a tube.  I had fun trying to figure out a method of keeping the floating tubes inside of the pool.  Even though Maya can go outside of the pool, the tubes can not. At first, I had the tubes with a set angle and move, but then I made them random. When I tried to play, I would never win, so I adjusted the random range to make the game possible. I still am wondering how to record all three tubes have entered the green space as a success.  (i just figured out how to do this).  I also want to add bonus coconuts that will fall from the trees.  If Maya gets these, in the next level, she will have super powers. 

Music from Incompetech by Kevin McLeod  Undaunted.mp3
instructions: Use your keyboard arrows to move Maya's tube around to get all the floating tubes to the green space in the swimming pool.  You have 60 seconds to do so!  Good luck.

title: Messing About with Time
description:
Today I finally had more time to spend on my project, and yet this is the most unfinished, messy, experimental, uncomfortable thing I've shared so far.

In my countless experiments I came up with clocks that made much more sense and looked better than this one. I've saved some of them, and took apart many others. But I choose to share this one because is the one I learned the most from.

If you look inside at the code you'll see an explosion of blocks all over the place.. I think they are sound evidence of a deep tinkering process and a rich creative learning experience, something that should be valued rather than stigmatized when we assess students' work.

I also learned a lot about clones and performance, continuously pushing the boundaries to see what was possible to achieve, instead of changing strategies, even when I could see a better alternative solution.

I prioritized inquiry, exploration and investigation over efficiency and getting "right answers" or making the "right project", in the spirit described in the wonderful article shared today: http://www.papert.org/articles/ComputerAsMaterial.htm

Anyway, I have many other reflections about time.. but I'll share them another time. Now it's time for me to go to bed! I hadn't noticed because my clock here only counts seconds.. at this time! :)

Until next time!
instructions: Click the green flag and... see the result of more than 4 hours of messing about with time.

title: mechanical clock
description:
Getting Unstuck day 10
by Massimo Marletta

In this project I simulated how a mechanical clock works.
The project is not intended to be a precise clock (there are obviously better ways to do it).
A pendulum is used as oscillator, performing a regular motion depending on its length (physics tells us how the period is related to the length and it is unrelated to the mass). At each 1/4 of period the pendulum raise an impulse (actually a broadcast message to the needles). Each needle when receive the impulse rotates of a fixed amount, depending on the period of the pendulum and the "role" of the needle (hours, minutes, seconds). In reality it depends on the gears that connect needles to the mechanism.
The user can change the length of the pendulum and see the results.
The pendulum block uses the Timer to establish at which time raise the broadcast message.
instructions:
In this project I simulated how a mechanical clock works.
The project is not intended to be a precise clock (there are obviously better ways to do it).

Select the length of the oscillating pendulum that giver the impulse to the needles to rotate.

A pendulum is used as oscillator, performing a regular motion depending on its length (physics tells us how the period is related to the length and it is unrelated to the mass). At each 1/4 of period the pendulum raise an impulse (actually a broadcast message to the needles). Each needle when receive the impulse rotates of a fixed amount, depending on the period of the pendulum and the "role" of the needle (hours, minutes, seconds). In reality it depends on the gears that connect needles to the mechanism.

*** Update ***
- Now the clock synchronizes with the real time clock when the green flag is pressed (seconds excluded so that orange needle always starts at 00).
- Seconds counter added (it counts pendulum ticks and scales to seconds)
- Press Space Bar the follow the clock of 100 pendulum ticks

description:

What would you do next with your project, if you had more time? I would make it more interactively smooth rather than having to start and stop to get new numbers.
instructions: Move Scratch to touch one or more of the colored circles. Then, press the green arrow. Use the space bar to reset all numbers.

title: Unstuck Day 10
description: I originally made it so the information would be displayed as you see it on the first screen.  I then figured out how to "say" the days of the week and the month in words rather than just numbers.

title: Unstuck - Day 10
description: For this project, my daughter and I still have some questions. We kept this simple - we only asked "What year were you born?" and gave an estimated age as the answer.  To determine the actual age, we would need the day, month and year. We will be checking out other people's projects to see if anyone else figured out how to tell the exact age.  I predict that you would need to use if-then blocks, and possibly some variables.
instructions: Click on the green flag and answer the question.

title: Getting Unstuck Day 10
description:
Getting Unstuck Day 10 Reflection:
These challenges are definitely getting harder!  I'm not thrilled with how this turned out, but after a lot of trial and error I figured out how to get the timer to show up.  I don't see how to stop it at the end of the race though.  It just keeps tracking time until you start the game over again (or hide the timer, but I wanted to freeze it on the time.  If that had worked, I would have had the player "drive" the car and play against my self-driving car.  :)
instructions: Click the green flag to start the timer, then click on the car to start the race.  (Don't worry, it's a self-driving car, so just sit back and enjoy the ride!).

title: 10 : Julekalenderen - Christmas calendar
description:
I have wanted to make a Christmas calendar for some years now - it is so great with these tasks - now I know how after getting the idea from CompTeacherK5s project with the count down to Happy New Year! 

I found this beautiful background here: https://pixabay.com/da/julen-juletr%C3%A6-baggrund-struktur-3029496/ 
The stop sprite here: https://pixabay.com/da/knapper-multimedie-pause-afspilning-150350/
Christmas music was found here: http://www.freexmasmp3.com/
And Santa Claus from here https://opengameart.org/content/christmas-charactes-zombie-santa-weapons
instructions:
Det er en julekalender, som er lavet i meget god tid. Du kan kun åbne lågerne, når vi når til december 2018 - medmindre du klikker 2 gange på lågen. Der sker noget særligt ved lågerne 1, 2, 9 og 24. Husk lyd.

You can only open the boxes in December 2018. But if you can't wait - click on the box twice. So far it only works with the boxes 1,2,9 and 24. Remember sound. Work-in-progress - new fully version will be made before December in Scratch 3.0.

title: Getting Unstuck: Day 10
description:
Getting Unstuck: Day 10 

This one was fun! I need to play around more with the actual timer functions, but I think I'm off to a good start so far. 

Shout out to CompTeacherK5 for the countdown idea!
instructions: Click the green flag.

title: Getting Unstuck Day 10 Car Game
description:
Made for day 10 of getting unstuck creative computing.
I quite like the controls for this game, using the left and right to steer with acceleration.
I'd like to look into making this into a game with a cloud variable and a high score list. I've never used them before but I think they have always been a feature of Scratch 2.0.
instructions:
Click the Green Flag to start and reset the timer.
Use the arrow keys to control the car.
Left and right rotate the car.
Up and down accelerate and decelerate.
Space acts as a break.
See how quickly you can get to the finish line.

title: Unstuck Day 10 - Using Time
description: This project creates a different design using different colors depending on when you start it. It uses current time and date data, so in theory it will never create the same design twice.
instructions: Just hit the green flag.

title: Beat Beetle - GettingUnstuck-10
description:
It always plays a regular beat, so I'd like to add different rhythms and make things funnier. It may also declare that you've missed a beat.
In this period I'm really interested in musical experimentation decided that the request for day10 may be a good way to start working on rhythms
instructions:
Green flag to start.
Change the beat with the cursor: you will hear a drum playing the rhythm. Click the beetle at the correct instant to get a point, it gets more difficult as the tempo gets slower.
The drum changes with the value of the second at which it's played (to get things harder)

title: Getting Unstuck - Day 10
description:
Today's challenge is to "Create a project that uses one or more of the time-related blocks in the Sensing category (i.e., timer, reset timer, current [year/month/date/etc.], days since 2000)".

I knew I wanted to be able to move my sprite around and have it catch a regenerating object.  I had to search a lot to figure out the timer.  All the YouTube videos I watched used a variable for the timer, which was NOT the challenge.  I finally began searching the scratch wikis and that helped me figure out that the timer will not stop, it will only reset.  So then I just had to program the score variable to stop after 15 seconds and make sure when the game started that everything reset to 0.  Then it was a little bit of a struggle to get the start/during/end backgrounds to do what I wanted.

Credit my daughter for the idea of creating Scratch's cape!

If I could change it... I would write a script to either stop the timer or make it hide after 15 seconds.
instructions:
Click the Green Arrow to show the starting screen.

Then click the space bar to start the game.
Use the arrows to move and change the directions of the cat.

How many tacos can you catch in 15 seconds?
